title: Angles üó£Ô∏è
Read & React Layer 1: Pass & Cut Excerpt

teachingPoints.teachingPoint_short_description:
This is the simplest version of the 5-out formation, designed to teach the core concepts of pass‚Äìcut‚Äìreplace.

Rules:
1) If you pass, you must cut ‚Äì either to the basket or through to the weak side.
 2) If a teammate cuts and you're next to the open space, you must replace to keep the spacing.

We start the action from corner to corner to help players follow a consistent sequence that‚Äôs easy to learn. While this isn't a true game-like movement yet, it builds the foundation for understanding timing, spacing, and decision-making in motion offense.

Rules:
1) If you pass, you must cut ‚Äì either to the basket or through to the weak side.
 2) If a teammate cuts and you're next to the open space, you must replace to keep the spacing.

This is an important foundation for building on top of this system.

Rule:
1) If you are one pass away from the ball and your defender has a foot over the 3-point line (deny position), you must cut ‚Äî to the basket and through to the weak side.

Why this matters:
a) You have the advantage of speed (defender has back to basket).  If your defender is over the 3-point line with their back to the basket, and both you and your defender are equally quick, you will beat them to the rim every time ‚Äî because you can see and react first.

b) Cutting keeps the offense flowing.
If you don‚Äôt cut when your defender is denying, you clog up spacing and freeze the weak side.
But if you do cut, you open up the floor ‚Äî creating space for teammates to fill, move, and cut into.
It turns a stagnant setup into a dynamic offense.

title: The Pistol Offense

teachingPoints.teachingPoint_short_description:
A Pistol action is a dribble hand-off immediately followed by a ball screen. 

This sequence forces the defense to navigate two consecutive actions back-to-back.

The goal is to disrupt defensive coverage, creating opportunities through:
- Switches (ie defenders switch - hard to do effectively, giving advantantage to ball handler)
- Dribble penetration (or PnR)
- Drive-and-kick options
Main video has a number of different outcomes.
In this variation, the ball handler rejects the hand off for open lane to basket.

title: Drill Big Man Post Play and Up and Under

teachingPoints.teachingPoint_short_description:
4 kids.

wing and low post - both sides.

start wing, shotfake then > pass into low post
low post receive (drop step/turn and shoot)
rebound and kick out to opposite side to reset.

4 kids.

wing and low post - both sides.

start wing, shotfake, side step > pass into low post
low post receive (pivot - either baseline or to foul line) > shot fake and score.
If you need to dribble (only 1 once between legs) - but try to avoid it)

rebound and kick out to opposite side to reset.
